titlepage.titleproper: Peter W. Van Winkle papers, 1861-1866, 1917, circa 1951-1957
titlepage.publisher: University of Wyoming. American Heritage Center.

did.head: Collection Summary

physdesc.label: Size
physdesc.extent: 0.25 cubic ft. (1 slim document box and 1 oversize folder + artifacts)

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: University of Wyoming. American Heritage Center.

did.abstract: The collection contains muster rolls, returns, and other records of Company D (1862-1866), a photograph of Peter W. Van Winkle (circa 1860s), and a brief biography of the Van Winkle family by Nellie W. Baum (circa 1951). The artifacts comprise of a sash, insignia, and an epaulette box of Capt. Van Winkle’s and a drawing of Fort Laramie during the time the Van Winkle family lived there. Also included with the collection are a funeral notice for Caspar Collins (1866) and copies of articles by C.O. Collins about his experiences with the 11th Ohio Volunteer Cavalry (1917).

bioghist.head: Biography of Peter W. Van Winkle
bioghist.p: Peter Weldon Van Winkle was captain of Company D, 11th Ohio Volunteer Cavalry between 1862 and 1866. He was born March 9, 1825, near Hillsboro, Ohio, and helped to organize the 11th Ohio Volunteer Cavalry in 1861. Most of the men in Company D were residents of Highland County, Ohio. The company was stationed at Fort Laramie and at Platte Bridge Station. After the company had been at Fort Laramie for a time, Captain Van Winkle’s wife, Margaret Kinkead Van Winkle, and two daughters, Mary Eliza (12) and a younger girl (6) joined him. Margaret and the girls were sent home again in 1864 during the Sioux war. Van Winkle suffered a stroke while on duty and was sent home to Hillsboro, Ohio, where he died on August 2, 1871.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection contains muster rolls, returns, and other records of Company D (1862-1866), a photograph of Peter W. Van Winkle (circa 1860s), and a brief biography of the Van Winkle family by Nellie W. Baum (circa 1951). The artifacts comprise a sash, insignia, and an epaulette box of Capt. Van Winkle’s and a primitive-style drawing of Fort Laramie during the time that the Van Winkle family lived there. Also included with the collection are a funeral notice for Caspar Collins (1866) and copies of articles by C. O. Collins about his experiences with the 11th Ohio Volunteer Cavalry (1917).

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: There are no access restrictions on the materials for research purposes, and the collection is open to the public.

userestrict.head: Copyright Information
userestrict.p: The researcher assumes full responsibility for observing all copyright, property, and libel laws as they apply.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: There are no other known archival collections created by Peter W. Van Winkle at the date of processing.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The papers were received from Nellie W. (Mrs. Fred T.) Baum in 1951 and 1957. Fred Terrell Baum was the son of Mary Eliza Van Winkle (Baum).

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by D.C. Thompson in June 2002.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Item Description, Box Number, Folder Number, Peter W. Van Winkle papers, 1861-1866, 1917, circa 1951-1957, Collection Number 00186, American Heritage Center, University of Wyoming.
